zone.line: aberrations of the fixed stars. It is our
distance from them and our imper-
fect means of communication that
makes them appear to move; in ll
truth they always remain stationary,
a glorious centre, leach giving us
a fine lesson of modesty if we would
thus receive it." â€“
I have said that he was a poet:
When he was three and twenty years
of age he first published a poem, and
it was hailed by the whole nation
with enthusiasm and delight: His
good star perpetually shone upon
him; a reputation had never before
been made so rapidly: it was uni
versal. The multitude extolled the
same poems that formed the wonder
of the sage in his closet: there was not
one dissentient voice.
It was at this time, in the height
of his glory, that he became acquainted
with Elinor. She was a young heiress of
